intro: Mariscus thomensis, commonly known as the Tomé's mariscus, is a flowering plant native to the island of São Tomé in the Gulf of Guinea. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that are typically pink or white in color. The plant has a woody stem and produces small, elliptical leaves that are often covered in a fine, hairy texture. It thrives in humid, tropical climates and is often found in shaded, moist forest environments. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
